UserProfile.title: UserProfile
UserProfile.description: Represents a user profile in the CareerCompass app.

id.description: Unique identifier for the UserProfile entity.

registrationDate.description: Date and time the user registered.

QuizQuestion.title: QuizQuestion
QuizQuestion.description: Represents a quiz question in the CareerCompass app.

id.description: Unique identifier for the QuizQuestion entity.

text.description: The text of the quiz question.

options.description: Array of possible answer options for the question.

correctAnswerIndex.description: Index of the correct answer in the options array.

interestArea.description: The area of interest this question assesses (e.g., analytical, creative, social).

QuizResponse.title: QuizResponse
QuizResponse.description: Represents a user's response to a quiz question.

id.description: Unique identifier for the QuizResponse entity.

selectedOptionIndex.description: The index of the option selected by the user.

responseTimestamp.description: Timestamp of when the user submitted the response.

CareerPath.title: CareerPath
CareerPath.description: Represents a career path option for students.

id.description: Unique identifier for the CareerPath entity.

name.description: Name of the career path (e.g., Engineering, Medicine).

description.description: Detailed description of the career path.

requiredSkills.description: List of required skills for this career path.

requiredCourses.description: List of recommended courses for this career path.

averageSalary.description: Average salary expectations for this career path.

futureScope.description: Future scope and outlook for this career path.

UserCareerPreference.title: UserCareerPreference
UserCareerPreference.description: Represents a user's saved career path preference. Denormalizes some career data for efficient reads on the 'Favorites' page.

id.description: The ID of the career, copied from the CareerPath entity. Used as the document ID.

slug.description: Denormalized slug of the career for URL generation.

stream.description: Denormalized stream of the career (e.g., Science, Commerce).

description.description: Denormalized short description of the career.

isFavorite.description: Indicates if the user marked this career path as a favorite. Always true for documents in this collection.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to ensure security, scalability, and ease of debugging, following the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, and DBAC. It leverages denormalization and structural segregation to simplify security rules and enable secure list operations. The primary strategy is to create hierarchical paths for user-owned data and to use membership maps for collaborative data when needed (although the current application doesn't present a clear collaborative model).  Since there is no collaborative content the membership map strategy is not used. The design assumes that Firebase Authentication provides the user's identity (`request.auth.uid`).

**Authorization Independence (CRITICAL):** All subcollections requiring access control based on parent data include denormalized fields. For example, `QuizResponse` documents under `/users/{userId}/quiz_responses/{quizResponseId}` inherently inherit authorization context through the path structure, eliminating the need for `get()` calls in security rules. This is achieved through path-based ownership which implicitly ties the data to the authenticated user.

**Clarity of Intent (Debuggability):** The structure clearly reflects the relationships between entities. User profiles are stored in a dedicated collection (`/users/{userId}`), and user-specific data like quiz responses and career preferences are nested under the user's document. The naming conventions are explicit.

**DBAC (No Custom Claims):** Roles are not explicitly modeled in the database according to the instructions. Authorization is based on `request.auth.uid` and the path structure.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):** The structure supports secure `list` operations. For instance, listing favorites for a user is done via `/users/{userId}/career_preferences`, which allows filtering based on the authenticated user's ID in security rules, preventing unauthorized access to other users' data.

**Invariants:** The structure supports the integrity of ownership. The `/users/{userId}/career_preferences/{careerId}` collection uses the ID of the career as the document ID for quick 'is-favorite' checks. It also stores denormalized career data (title, slug, etc.) to avoid expensive joins when listing favorites, making the 'My Favorites' page faster and more efficient.
